div0.head: *w
div0.entryFree:
*w, w)=, to/, twenty-fourth and last letter of the Ionic alphabet,
a)po\ a)/lfa e(/ws .w.
Gloss. iii 283
(ix A. D.); thence used as a symbol of
the end, the last, e)gw/ ei)mi to\ a)/lfa kai\ to\ w)= (not to\ w)= me/ga) Apoc. 1.8 , al.:—as a numeral w/ =
800 , but wNUM =
800 , 000 . The epichoric Att. and other alphabets of the Inscrr. had used o in differently to represent the sounds of the later o and w : *w is a differentiated form of o, and, though usu. = w, was used in the Ionic islands of Paros, Thasos, and Siphnos with the value o, while O or O represented the sound w. The name of the letter was to\ w)= (perispom. acc. to Hellad. ap. Phot. p.530B. ), cf. Achae. 33.3 , Pl. Phdr. 244d , Cra. 420b , Tht. 203c : after the loss of the distinction betw. long and short vowels, o and w had the same pronunciation; they begin to be confused in Papyri of iii B. C. ( oi)kwno/mou
PRev.Laws 50.22
(iii B. C.)), but the name w me/ga appears first in later Greek, Theognost. Can. 13 ; kata\ sxh=ma diplou= w_ h)/toi mega/lou
Eust. 869.26
; oi( de\ peri\ *)ari/starxon au)to\ to\ poth/rion w_ me/ga ei)=nai/ fasin, o(poi=n i)/sws to\ kata\ du/o u_ e)sxhmatisme/non
Id. 869.29
; e)n tw=| w_ mega/lw| under
omega (in a lexicon), Id. 1828.49 : dia\ tou^ w_ mega/lou
Hdn. Epim. 208
.

w)= and w)/, an exclamation, expressing surprise, joy, or pain,
O! oh! with nom., w)\ ta/las e)gw/
S. Aj. 981
, etc.; w)\ e)/benos, w)\ xruso/s
Theoc. 15.123
: also c. gen., w)\ th=s a)naisxunti/as
Luc. Pisc. 5
; with interrog., w)/, ti/ le/geis;
Pl. Prt. 309d
; in the middle of a sentence, E. Hipp. 362 (lyr.), al. with voc., a mode of address, whether at the beginning of a sentence or in a parenthesis, w)= *)axileu=
Il. 1.74
, etc., esp. in dialogue and Oratt., e)boulo/mhn, w)= a)/ndres, th\n du/namin ktl. Antipho. 5.1 ; in invocations of the gods, w)= *zeu= te kai\ *gh= kai\ polissou=xoi qeoi/
A. Th. 69
, etc.; with imper., w)= xai=re
Id. Ag. 22
, S. Aj. 91 ; w)= pro\s qew=n u(/peike ib. 371 , cf. D. 21.98 : sts. following the Verb, E. Tr. 335 (lyr.); in different number from the voc., prose/lqet', w)= pai=, patri/
S. OC 1104
, cf. 1112 , Sch. Ar. Pl. 66 . with nom. instead of voc., w)= di^os ai)qh/r, w)= fi/los,
A. Pr. 88 , 545 ; w)= gennai=os
Pl. Phdr. 227c
; w)= ou(=tos *ai)/as
S. Aj. 89
; w)= ou(=tos ou(=tos *oi)di/pous
Id. OC 1627
; also ou(=tos, w)= se/ toi (sc. kalw=) Ar. Av. 274 . with both together, fi/los w)= *mene/lae
Il. 4.189
; w)= tla/mwn pa/ter
S. Aj. 641
(lyr., tla=mon codd. rec., edd.). with the latter of two nouns, *)aga/memnon, w)= *mene/lae
Id. Ph. 794
.—In the first sense usu. written w)/, in the second w)= : [to\ w)\] h(ni/ka qaumastiko\n lamba/netai baru/netai, kai\ xwrei^ ei)s e)pirrhmatikh\n su/ntacin, oi(=on w)\ *(hraklh=s
EM 79.13
: Thom.Mag. p.408R. prescribes w)\ with the gen., but w)= with the voc., e.g. w)= *(hra/kleis, where the whole expression, and not merely the w)/ (w)=,) expresses surprise (but A.D. Adv. 127.24 seems to imply w)= in both senses); w)/ as an exclam. is found in forms like w)/ moi, w)/ moi e)gw/, w)\ pro\s tw=n qew=n
D. l. c.: but w)= po/poi dusi\ to/nois xrh=tai Hdn.Gr. 1.503 , so that w)\ po/poi is improbable, cf. Theognost. Can. 158 (as emended by Lehrs Aristarch. 3p.119 ); w)/|moi and w)/moi are both recognized by EM 822.33 , cf. Lex.Mess. p.413 ; wim'
Sapph. Supp. 23.4
; in E. , when it stands in the middle of a sentence, it shd. be written w)/,
Hipp. 362 , al.: sts. doubled, w)\ w)\ kaka/
A. Ag. 1214
; i)w\ w)\ w)/
S. OC 224
( v.l. w(\ w(\ w(\ ); written w\ w/ in Pap. of S. Ichn. 61 ; tripled, w)\ w)\ w)/
A. Pers. 985
(lyr., prob.). To those who (like D.T. 640.11 , cf. Sch. D.T. p.257H. ) took w)= for the voc. of the Art. o(, A.D. Synt. 45.22 - 53 replies at length.

summit, dub. in Corinn. Supp. 1.26 .—Gramm. vary in spelling, o)/a
Poll. 7.62
, Hdn.Gr. 2.271 ; o)/a and w)/|a
Hsch.
; w)=|a
Theognost. Can. 106
; w)=a

(v. supr.), quoting Ael.Dion. Fr. 266 (whose lexicon gave both o)/a and w)=|a) and an anonymous lexicon which gave o)ai\ i(mati/wn (o)cuto/nws kai\ sunestalme/nws, =
Ar. Fr. 228 ): SIG 1259 (v. supr.) is by a half-educated writer: Eust. considers w)/|a to be contr. from oi)e/h or o)i/+a,
877.53 , 1828.51 .

w)/a (B),
v. w)ba/ , cf. oi)/h (A).

*)widei=on, to/,
the Odeum, a public building at Athens built by Pericles
for musical performances (w)|dai/), having an orchestra, And. 1.38 , IG 22.1688.3 , Eup. 18D. ; and other apparatus of a theatre, Paus. 1.8.6 , 1.14.1 ; used as a law-court, Ar. V. 1109 (troch., cf. Sch.), D. 59.52 ; for philos. disputations, Alex. 25.2 , D.L. 7.184 , Plu. 2.605a ; for soldiers' quarters, X. HG 2.4.9 , 24 ; as a place for distributing corn, D. 34.37 : it seems to have been circular, with a peaked roof, whence the line of Cratin. 71 , o( sxinoke/falos *zeu\s o(di\ prose/rxetai o( *perikle/hs, tw)|dei=on e)pi\ tou= krani/ou e)/xwn, cf. Plu. Per. 13 , Thphr. Char. 3.4 : rebuilt, after having been burnt, by Ariobarzanes, App. Mith. 38 . of other
music-halls, as that at Athens, built by Herodes Atticus, Paus. 7.20.6 ; at Corinth, Id. 2.3.6 ; at Patrae, Id. 7.20.6 ; at Patara, Epigr.Gr. 412 ; at Samos, GDI 5702.41
(iv B. C.); at Rome, built by Hadrian, D.C. 69.4 ; qeatroeide\s w)|.

(Palestine).
